articles.headline: OPEC Plans Further Output Cut
articles.snippet: The cartel will slash its oil production by a further 2 million barrels a day, the Saudi oil minister said.
articles.abstract: The cartel will slash its oil production by a further 2 million barrels a day, the Saudi oil minister said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The OPEC cartel is preparing to announce its biggest production cut in decades, as producers struggle to contain a collapse in prices amid a global recession, Saudi Arabian and other OPEC representatives said Tuesday.

articles.headline: Fed Cuts Key Rate to a Record Low
articles.snippet: Having reduced its key rate to a record low, the Fed said that it would use “all available tools” to fight the recession and downward pressure on prices.
articles.abstract: Having reduced its key rate to a record low, the Fed said that it would use “all available tools” to fight the recession and downward pressure on prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve entered a new era on Tuesday, lowering its benchmark interest rate virtually to zero and declaring that it would now fight the recession by pumping out vast amounts of money to businesses and consumers through an expanding array of new lending programs.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Electoral Rot Nearby? The Russians Don’t See It
articles.snippet: In bolstering authoritarian regimes in neighboring states, the Kremlin helps create the illusion of democracy.
articles.abstract: In bolstering authoritarian regimes in neighboring states, the Kremlin helps create the illusion of democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHODINO, Belarus  The voting monitor began his rounds on election day here at Polling Place No. 7. “Issues? Violations?” he asked the poll workers, glancing around like a casual sightseer. They said no, so he left.

articles.headline: Finding Good News in Falling Prices
articles.snippet: It’s worth considering what may be the one silver lining in the incredibly bad run of recent economic news: The cost of living is falling.
articles.abstract: It’s worth considering what may be the one silver lining in the incredibly bad run of recent economic news: The cost of living is falling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Very few Americans alive today can remember a time when prices across the economy were falling. But they’re falling now.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Says It Missed Signals on Madoff Fraud Case
articles.snippet: The commission said that there were repeated opportunities to uncover the alleged scheme by Bernard L. Madoff, a Wall Street executive.
articles.abstract: The commission said that there were repeated opportunities to uncover the alleged scheme by Bernard L. Madoff, a Wall Street executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday night that it had missed repeated opportunities to discover what may be the largest financial fraud in history, a Ponzi scheme whose losses could run as high as $50 billion.
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: In Fraud Case, Middlemen in Spotlight
articles.snippet: Walter M. Noel and his firm now have the distinction of being the biggest known losers in the Madoff scandal.
articles.abstract: Walter M. Noel and his firm now have the distinction of being the biggest known losers in the Madoff scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a go-between who shepherded clients and their money to Bernard L. Madoff, Walter M. Noel became so prosperous that he was only too happy to show off his good fortune to the world.

articles.headline: Bush Prepares Crisis Briefings to Aid Obama
articles.snippet: The White House has created contingency plans to help Barack Obama in the event of an early crisis.
articles.abstract: The White House has created contingency plans to help Barack Obama in the event of an early crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House has prepared more than a dozen contingency plans to help guide President-elect Barack Obama if an international crisis erupts in the opening days of his administration, part of an elaborate operation devised to smooth the first transition of power since Sept. 11, 2001.

articles.headline: Obama Pledge Stirs Hope in Early Education
articles.snippet: A $10 billion promise would be the largest new initiative for young children since Head Start began in 1965.
articles.abstract: A $10 billion promise would be the largest new initiative for young children since Head Start began in 1965.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  It was the morning after the presidential election, and Matthew Melmed, executive director of Zero to Three, a national organization devoted to early childhood education, could barely contain his exultation.

articles.headline: European Banks Tally Losses Linked to Fraud
articles.snippet: The size of Bernard L. Madoff’s scheme calls into question why big banks in Spain, Britain and especially Switzerland failed to spot the risks of putting billions into Mr. Madoff’s hands.
articles.abstract: The size of Bernard L. Madoff’s scheme calls into question why big banks in Spain, Britain and especially Switzerland failed to spot the risks of putting billions into Mr. Madoff’s hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  In early 2003, as word of Bernard L. Madoff’s apparent Midas touch spread among affluent Europeans and money managers, a team from Société Générale’s investment bank here was sent to New York to perform some routine due diligence.

articles.headline: Geography Has Role in Medicare Cancer Coverage
articles.snippet: A treatment for prostate cancer highlights the disparities in Medicare reimbursements in different states.
articles.abstract: A treatment for prostate cancer highlights the disparities in Medicare reimbursements in different states.
articles.lead_paragraph: The medical tool’s catchy name, CyberKnife, evokes digital accuracy. But the way the federal Medicare system treats CyberKnife seems anything but precise.

articles.headline: 35 Iraq Officials Held in Raids on Key Ministry
articles.snippet: The arrested officials, who included four generals, have been accused of quietly working to reconstitute Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party.
articles.abstract: The arrested officials, who included four generals, have been accused of quietly working to reconstitute Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Up to 35 officials in the Iraqi Ministry of the Interior ranking as high as general have been arrested over the past three days with some of them accused of quietly working to reconstitute Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party, according to senior security officials in Baghdad.
articles.byline: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and TARIQ MAHER
